title: Investors say price uncertainty is driving up costs
text:
Her views were backed by Macquarie, one of world's largest investors in renewable capacity globally.

Brian Morris, a Macquarie divisional director, said while domestic and international super funds are ready to invest in Australian energy infrastructure – and had committed around $35 billion of funding to the sector in the last year – “what they do need is certainty”.

Areas this is most needed include connecting new energy sources to the grid and modelling of long-term prices. “These are quite difficult at the moment, and that is impacting the ability to invest,” he said.

ANZ Banking Group's head of project and sustainable finance, Paul Orton, also said banks require more detail on grid connection plans and the integration of renewables already in the system.

Need a better plan

While the institutional investment and Australian banking sector had stepped up to deliver the financing required to meet the Renewable Energy Target, and there was still healthy appetite to fund renewable projects, Mr Orton said “we have got to the point where we are starting to see the challenge of how we introduce this amount of renewable energy into the market – how you manage the system security and connections and integration".

Ms Herd called for a more co-ordinated national plan "which is not a series of ad hoc interventions to deal with portions of the issue, but rather an integrated understanding of both supply and demand factors, technology change, the genuine industry acknowledgement of decarbonisation drivers, and understanding how different providers will come in and out of the market".

"Without that plan, everyone will continue to price every variable because every variable is on the table and has a price," she said.

Advertisement

Ian Learmonth, CEO of the Clean Energy Finance Corp (CEFC), which has committed $6.6 billion to renewable projects, said there were plenty of "growing pains" as more renewable energy supply comes into the system. He cited 'marginal loss factors' in the grid and the need for more pump storage and gas peakers.

"The regulatory market doesn’t provide for straightforward business case" for these projects, he said, which has led the CEFC with the government's balance sheet to back projects.

But more consideration was needed on the supply of grant funding and to whether CEFC might write derivative contracts, he said.

Financiers on Thursday also pointed to the timing mismatch in price purchase agreements, which are typically written for 10 years on projects with a notional life as long as 20 years. This means debt and equity investors are taking a big risk for back half of the life of wind and solar projects.

Mr Orton said margin loss and connection issues would "impact on the view of equity investors, and that’s a reason the sector might slow for a period of time".
description: The Investor Group on Climate Change has called for a "narrowing of the spectrum of uncertainty" in energy investment.
